instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3023: What is 820-3023? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PPVRTC_G3H: What is PPVRTC_G3H? PPVRTC_G3H is a 3.3v power rail for the RTC circuit present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state. .
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.5V_S0: What is 5V_S0? 5V_S5 is an abbreviation for “PP5V_S0”.
definitions.3V3_S0: What is 3V3_S0? Abbreviation for PP3V3_S0, a 3.3v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_AXG: What is PPVCORE_S0_AXG? This is vcore going to the CPU’s integrated graphics processor for CPUs that have an integrated GPU. When this is missing on a device that has an integrated GPU and no discrete GPU, it usually means either no screen is detected, or the GPU integrated into the CPU is dead..
definitions.ALLSYS_PWRGD: What is ALLSYS_PWRGD? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALLSYS_PWRGD, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.
definitions.R7402: What is R7402? Resistor between PPVIN_S0_CPUIMVP and CPUIMVP_TON. TON stands for TIME ON – CPUIMVP_TON configures the buck converter for the CPU based on its input power supply. If this resistor is blown, the machine will turn on but not have any image, chime, or POST, because CPU vcore will be missing. This resistor is often the first to corrode because it is along a high voltage rail and it is right on the edge of the board, check this on 2011-2012 model Macbook Pros that turn on and do not chime. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU Vcore
threads.message:
This board was said to have liquid damage but I can't find much of any except for a little on the I/O Board. There are discolored probe points in places but I don't see any corrosion anywhere.

Anyways, the fans turn on when the charger is plugged in but nothing appears on the screen and there is no vcore. I do feel the <CHIP>U1800</CHIP> chip get slightly warm so I think the PCH is working. 
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVRTC_G3H</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>5V_S0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>3V3_S0</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>ALLSYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> were all present.

<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_AXG</SIGNAL> show 0v but <SIGNAL>PP1V5_S3_CPU_VCCDQ</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0_CPU_VCCPQE</SIGNAL>, and <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0_CPU_VCCPLL_R</SIGNAL> all had the correct voltage on them.

I'm not sure exactly where to start in troubleshooting vcore on this model.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU Vcore
threads.message:
Update: I went to the <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> Chip to troubleshoot and I noticed the <SIGNAL>IMVP_TON</SIGNAL> resistor was corroded on one side so I replaced it and now this machine is working perfectly fine and vcore is back.

This can be marked solved.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU Vcore
threads.message: Check <CHIP>U7400</CHIP> area, pin 1 should of course have 3V and <RESISTOR>R7401</RESISTOR>/2 are suspect.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3023</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no CPU Vcore
threads.message: [USER="2"]dukefawks[/USER] Yes. I posted an update message at the same time you posted your message. <RESISTOR>R7402</RESISTOR> turned out to be the issue so this can be marked solved.
